<S ssid="1" sid="50">Table 2 shows a comparison with some existing toolkits that build deterministic, minimized automata/transducers.</S><S ssid="1" sid="1">Foma is a compiler, programming language, and C library for constructing finite-state automata and transducers for various uses.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="3">Foma is largely compatible with the Xerox/PARC finite-state toolkit.</S><S ssid="1" sid="0">Foma: a finite-state compiler and library</S><S ssid="1" sid="1">Foma is a compiler, programming language, and C library for constructing finite-state automata and transducers for various uses.</S>
<S ssid="1" sid="7">One of Foma’s design goals has been compatibility with the Xerox/PARC toolkit.</S><S ssid="1" sid="3">Foma is largely compatible with the Xerox/PARC finite-state toolkit.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="14">The API also contains, mainly for spell-checking purposes, functionality for finding words that match most closely (but not exactly) a path in an automaton.</S><S ssid="1" sid="32">Below is a simple example of the format: Multichar_Symbols +Pl +Sing LEXICON Root Nouns; LEXICON Nouns cat Plural; church Plural; LEXICON Plural +Pl:%ˆs #; +Sing #;</S>
